author: Emma O'Brien
title: Stock Futures Signal Slump After Apple Results; Oil Resumes Drop
text:
U.S. equity-index futures slipped after Apple Inc. and Microsoft Corp. reported disappointing results, signaling the steepest technology stock rally since October may be coming to an end. Crude oil resumed losses.
Contracts on the Nasdaq 100 Index lost 1.1 percent by 8:05 a.m. in Tokyo, as futures on the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index and Dow Jones Industrial Average sank 0.4 percent. Apple slid more than 6 percent in extended U.S. trading after revenue and iPhone shipments undershot analysts’ estimates. Microsoft fell 4 percent on its record net loss. Asian index futures were also lower, with the yen and euro holding rebounds versus the dollar. U.S. crude fell 0.5 percent after rallying Tuesday.
Should Apple’s after-market drop be realized, it would erase more than $50 billion from the tech giant’s value, furthering a retreat in the Nasdaq Composite Index, which reached a record on Monday following Google Inc.’s earnings. Declining sales at International Business Machines Corp., released during the U.S. trading day, helped drive down the Dow by the most in almost two weeks. Australia reports on inflation Wednesday amid an increase in gold prices, and Indonesian markets resume after holidays.
“Right now, it’s about earnings, where they’re coming in and what they’re seeing for next quarter, and when the Fed is going to eventually raise rates,” said Thomas Garcia, head of equity trading at Santa Fe, New Mexico-based Thornburg Investment Management Inc.
Apple Suppliers Shares of Apple suppliers traded in the U.S. fell in after-market trading, raising the likelihood of declines among Asian firms that work with the world’s most valuable company by market capitalization. Apple slid as much as 8.8 percent in extended trade, with iPhone shipments in the fiscal third quarter trailing analysts’ estimates and the revenue forecast of $49 billion to $51 billion falling short of the $51.1 billion average estimate of analysts.
Yahoo Inc. also declined, losing 1.5 percent in the post market after predicting sales for the current quarter that were below analysts’ estimates.
Yen-denominated futures on Japan’s Nikkei 225 Stock Average slipped 0.5 percent to 20,620, while contracts traded in the Osaka pre-market were bid for 20,640, from 20,840 in Japan Tuesday. The yen, which typically moves at odds with Japanese equities, was little changed at 123.85 per dollar after climbing 0.3 percent last session.
Dollar Drop The euro was steady at $1.0938 following a 1 percent rebound on Tuesday. The dollar retreated against most of its major peers last session amid a lull in economic data. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, which advanced 1.6 percent last week, fell 0.5 percent Tuesday, snapping a four-day rally. Investors are scrutinizing U.S. data to gauge the timeline for Federal Reserve interest-rate increases, with policy makers to meet next week.
Futures on the Kospi index in Seoul lost 0.4 percent, while contracts on Australia’s S&P/ASX 200 Index were down 0.5 percent in most recent trading. BHP Billiton Ltd., the world’s biggest mining company and the resource stock with the heaviest weighting in the Australian index, reported iron-ore output of 60 million tones for the fourth quarter, above the median analyst estimate for 58.9 million tons.
Contracts on Chinese stocks signaled a retreat, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.6 percent Tuesday in a fourth straight day of gains. Futures on the FTSE China A50 Index, a gauge of the biggest mainland-traded shares, slipped 0.4 percent along with those on the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, which tracks Hong Kong-listed mainland stocks. Hang Seng Index futures were down 0.3 percent.
Tuesday’s weakness in equity markets bolstered the appeal of U.S. government debt. Treasuries rose, sending two-year note yields down from their highest level in almost a month, as appetite for riskier assets waned. Ten-year Treasury yields slipped five basis points, or 0.05 percentage point, to 2.33 percent.
Copper futures rallied Wednesday, adding 0.2 percent to $2.4800 a pound on the Comex following three days of declines. Gold was up 0.2 percent to $1,103.22 an ounce after rising 0.4 percent last session.
